Award.AwardTitle: EMSW21-RTG: Research Training Group in Interactions of Representation Theory, Geometry and Combinatorics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is training of undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs at the research interface of combinatorics, geometry, and representation theory. This area includes enumerative geometry, geometric representation theory of infinite dimensional Lie algebras, corresponding quantized universal enveloping algebras, and of Hecke algebras. On the combinatorial side we will also focus on algebraic combinatorics and its applications. All these areas have seen fascinating progress in the last decade.

The project will be conducted with active involvement of graduate and undergraduate students and post-docs. These areas of mathematics are closely related to many recent developments in mathematical physics (the mathematical side of theoretical physics), mostly to quantum field theory, string theory, and statistical mechanics. Combinatorial problems which will be addressed also have direct applications in biology, for instance in the study of phylogenetic trees. This grant (in combination with other grants) will be used to fund a number of training workshops and master-classes on hot research topics aimed at post-doctoral fellows, graduate, and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this grant was to create and maintain a research and training group in combinatorics, representation theory and geometry in Berkeley and to conduct research in this field. The goal was achieved.

Over the period of the grant such group of graduate students,  some undergraduate students, postdocs and faculty, was active and its traditions are continuing. Faculty members involved in this grant provided guidance in research to students and postdocs. Most of the participating graduate students went off to postdoc positions, the postdocs moved on and the undergraduate students involved in this project went on to graduate schools. Research results ranged from representation theory to algebraic and symplectic geometry, and to various questions in combinatorics. Altogether participating graduate students and postdocs wrote more than 60 research papers with original research, of which more than 40 are already accepted in research-refereed journals and refereed conference proceedings. Others are going through the review process.  

One of the undergraduate students mentored as part of the grant became the valedictorian of the Berkeley class of 2016 and then she went on to graduate school at MIT. 

Here are some examples of really new results—all obtained by graduate students (to describe all results would not fit in this summary). First, cluster coordinates were developed for Kac-Moody groups. (Cluster coordinates can exist only for very special manifolds and they are extremely important for quantization; Kac-Moody groups is a special class of transformations of infinite dimensional spaces.) Second, one of the very important examples in stochastic processes is the Asymmetric Simple Exclusion Process. A simple combinatorial description was found for the probability distribution preserved by a family of natural generalizations of this process. Third, the most likely configuration of lattice paths in a model of random paths, a model which is closely related to the ASEP, was described in terms of simple nonlinear differential equation (Burgers type equation).
